body_html:
Also, note that you can just as well do

some_tensor = some_tensor[mask]

which internally performs nonzero for you.

It does. Neat :)

But... I have multiple tensor (~6 or so). Would this mean it would have to run nonzero multiple times? By the way, the current functionality does what I want, in terms of nonzero behavior. I'm pushing back against migrating nonzero to give tuples, which sounds pretty slow-tastic, cf a cuda-rized tensor?
body_text:
Also, note that you can just as well do
some_tensor = some_tensor[mask]
which internally performs nonzero for you.

It does. Neat :)
But... I have multiple tensor (~6 or so). Would this mean it would have to run nonzero multiple times? By the way, the current functionality does what I want, in terms of nonzero behavior. I'm pushing back against migrating nonzero to give tuples, which sounds pretty slow-tastic, cf a cuda-rized tensor?
body:
> Also, note that you can just as well do
> 
> some_tensor = some_tensor[mask]
> 
> which internally performs nonzero for you.

It does. Neat :)

But... I have multiple tensor (~6 or so). Would this mean it would have to run `nonzero` multiple times? By the way, the current functionality does what I want, in terms of nonzero behavior. I'm pushing back against migrating nonzero to give tuples, which sounds pretty slow-tastic, cf a cuda-rized tensor?
